item.title: Gunmen Kill 11 After Soccer Match in Mexico
item.description: The mass shooting occurred in an area fought over by drug cartels, just as the Mexican government has sought to show Washington that it is combating criminal groups.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: Mario Armas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Mexican National Guard members at the scene where 11 people were killed in Salamanca, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: Ralph Fiennes baila al ritmo de Iron Maiden en ‘El templo de huesos’
item.description: En una escena de la continuación de la saga de ‘Exterminio’, el personaje de Fiennes actúa al ritmo de la canción “The Number of the Beast”. Te contamos lo que sucedió detrás de cámara.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: Word of the Day: precursor
item.description: This word has appeared in 310 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: This Theory Explains Trump’s Baffling Foreign Policy
item.description: The president’s approach is not just chaos or an updated version of 19th-century great-power competition.
item.dc:creator: Stacie Goddard and Abraham L. Newman

item.title: ‘Bridgerton,’ Plus 5 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: This Regency-era drama is back for a fourth season, and the 2026 Grammy Awards will air.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

media:content.media:credit: Liam Daniel/Netflix
media:content.media:description: Luke Thompson and Yerin Ha in “Bridgerton.”

item.title: As Europe’s Reliance on U.S. Natural Gas Grows, So Does Trump’s Leverage
item.description: Tension over Greenland has prompted worries that the Trump administration could turn the U.S. oil and gas industry into a way to pressure Europe.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed

media:content.media:credit: Lisi Niesner/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A tanker waits to dock at a liquefied natural gas plant in Hammerfest, Norway, in 2024.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Maniacs Are His Specialty
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 26, 2026.

item.title: The Taliban Say They’re Ready to Release U.S. Prisoners. But Which Ones?
item.description: Top Afghan officials say they want two American detainees released “as soon as possible,” but the Trump administration says a third one should be included.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Adam Goldman

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Zabiullah Mujahid, the Taliban spokesman, in 2021. In a recent interview with The New York Times, he expressed the Taliban’s desire to secure the release of an Afghan inmate at Guantánamo Bay.

item.title: No Corrections: Jan. 26, 2026
item.description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 26, 2026.

item.title: Winter Storm Pummels Toronto With Near-Record Snowfall
item.description: Toronto Pearson International Airport had received about 18 inches by 10 p.m. on Sunday, the airport said, and snow was still falling.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

media:content.media:credit: Cole Burstona/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: People walking through downtown Toronto on Sunday.

item.title: Storm Dumps a Foot of Snow in at Least 17 U.S. States
item.description: Bonito Lake, N.M., received 31 inches, the most in the country, the National Weather Service said
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The East Village neighborhood of Manhattan on Sunday.

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1 Episode 2 Recap: A Man Among Princes
item.description: A certain royal family known for dragons and blond hair arrives on the scene. One of our heroes, at least, seems appropriately wary.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)

media:content.media:credit: Steffan Hill/HBO
media:content.media:description: Dunk and Egg (Peter Claffey, left, and Dexter Sol Ansell) have notably different reactions when the Targaryens ride onto the scene.

item.title: At Least 15 Dead After Ferry Carrying 350 Sinks in the Philippines
item.description: It was not immediately clear how many people were missing after the ferry sank early Monday morning in Basilan Province.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Private Jet With 8 People Aboard Crashes at Maine Airport, F.A.A. Says
item.description: A Bombardier Challenger 600 crashed during takeoff at the Bangor airport, according to officials, as a paralyzing winter storm lashed the East Coast.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri

item.title: Mamdani Clears Early Hurdles as Storm Bears Down on New York
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani made use of his strong communication skills, and the Sanitation Department said every road was plowed at least twice by Sunday evening.
item.dc:creator: Sally Goldenberg and Dana Rubinstein

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani was well aware that the snowstorm posed his first big management test.

item.title: Trump Blames Democrats for ‘Tragic’ Deaths as Agents Clash With Protesters
item.description: Top administration officials had earlier, and without evidence, accused each of the shooting victims in Minneapolis of “domestic terrorism.”
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Demonstrations after Alex Pretti was shot and killed by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: Alex Pretti’s Friends and Family Denounce ‘Sickening Lies’ About His Life
item.description: People who knew a man fatally shot by federal agents pushed back against what they called a smear campaign by federal officials. “He was a good man,” his family said.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg, Corina Knoll and Julie Bosman

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Alex Pretti’s friends and family said he was calm and generous with others.

item.title: Killing Prompts Only a Defiant Response From Trump
item.description: Even as the second death of a protester in Minnesota brought demands for accountability, the president, insulated from dissenting voices, stuck to his pattern of reflexively blaming opponents.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said on social media on Sunday that the blame for recent unrest lay, in part, with “Democrat run Sanctuary Cities and States.”

item.title: How the Trump Administration Rushed to Judgment in Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: The administration was in a race to control the narrative around the killing of Alex Pretti, even as videos emerged that contradicted the government’s account.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The rush to blame Mr. Pretti and exonerate the immigration agents deviated entirely from the way law enforcement investigations were normally carried out.

item.title: False Posts and Altered Images Distort Views of Minnesota Shooting
item.description: Some social media posts tried to warp the evidence of the killing of a nurse in Minneapolis, including in ways intended to support the Trump administration’s narrative about it.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu, Stuart A. Thompson and Steven Lee Myers

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: People gather around a makeshift memorial at the site where Alex Jeffrey Pretti, a 37 year old Minneapolis ICU nurse was shot and killed by U.S. Border Patrol agents, in Minneapolis, MN., on Sunday.

item.title: Winter Storm Blankets Eastern U.S. With Heavy Snow
item.description: A powerful winter storm brought heavy snow, ice and freezing cold from Texas to New England. Parts of the Northeast were expecting 12 to 18 inches of snow.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: Aristide Economopoulos for The New York Times

item.title: A Sunday Snowstorm Blankets New York
item.description: The city got about nine inches of snow and at least one person died from exposure to the cold as Mayor Zohran Mamdani faced his first big test in nuts-and-bolts governing.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jeremy Sukimoto shovels snow off his stoop in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

item.title: On Being Inconvenienced
item.description: After an alleged arson attack on a synagogue, one church in Jackson, Miss. opened its doors.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson

media:content.media:credit: Beth Israel Congregation, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: After the fire at Beth Israel.

item.title: George Cabot Lodge, Last of His Family to Battle a Kennedy, Dies at 98
item.description: The two Massachusetts clans faced off in elections for decades, until a final 1962 Senate race. Despite his loss, Mr. Lodge praised his opponent, Ted Kennedy.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

media:content.media:credit: Associated Press
media:content.media:description: George Cabot Lodge, right, and Edward M. Kennedy enjoying a laugh during their race to succeed Mr. Kennedy’s brother, John F. Kennedy, in the U.S. Senate in 1962.

item.title: In Visits to Dealerships, Pair Schemed to Steal High-End Vehicles, Police Say
item.description: An organized theft ring in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York swapped or quickly cloned key fobs to steal millions of dollars’ worth of vehicles, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

media:content.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A pouch designed to shield key fobs from cellular signals, which helps prevent remote or unauthorized access to vehicles. The police say a theft ring duplicated fobs to steal high-end vehicles.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 26, 2026
item.description: There’s a lot to love in Erica Hsiung Wojcik’s punny puzzle.
item.dc:creator: Peter Blair

media:content.media:credit: Mauricio Lima/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Hungry for a good puzzle?

item.title: Most Fox News Reporting on Minneapolis Shooting Supports Official Version
item.description: Fox anchors were laser focused on promoting the Trump administration’s narrative that the slain protester, Alex Pretti, had brought the violence upon himself.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A handmade sign memorializes Alex Pretti, who was shot and killed by immigration agents on Saturday in Minneapolis.

item.title: Columbia Selects University of Wisconsin Chancellor as Its President
item.description: Jennifer Mnookin has led the flagship campus of the state university system since 2022. She takes the helm at Columbia after a tumultuous period.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman

media:content.media:credit: Amber Arnold/Wisconsin State Journal, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Jennifer Mnookin, the chancellor of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, will assume the top role at Columbia University amid hopes she can restore stability.

item.title: People Protest Federal Immigration Agents After Fatal Shooting
item.description: People protested the death of Alex Jeffrey Pretti, whom federal agents fatally shot during demonstrations against a ramped-up immigration enforcement effort by the Trump administration. Federal officials said that Mr. Pretti had approached agents with a handgun and “wanted to do maximum damage.” But video from the scene shows Mr. Pretti was holding a phone, not a gun.
item.dc:creator: McKinnon de Kuyper and Rex Sakamoto

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: Another Fatal Shooting in Minneapolis
item.description: Events like this, where eyewitness video and independent reporting contradict the government’s account, highlight the importance of press freedom.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents confronted protesters in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: ¿Quién es Alex Jeffrey Pretti, el hombre abatido por el ICE?
item.description: Pretti, el hombre que murió tras recibir disparos de agentes migratorios, quería ser una “fuerza del bien en el mundo”.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll, Julie Bosman and Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Las protestas estallaron en Mineápolis, cerca del lugar donde agentes federales dispararon y mataron el sábado por la mañana a Alex Jeffrey Pretti, residente en Mineápolis de 37 años.

item.title: La tormenta invernal en EE. UU. en imágenes
item.description: Imágenes de gran parte del país muestran calles cubiertas de nieve y preparativos para lo peor que aún está por llegar.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Prospect Park in Brooklyn was pelted with snow.

item.title: What Is Thundersnow, One of Weather’s Rarest Spectacles
item.description: A clap of thunder can come as a surprise in the steady calm of falling snow. Here’s what causes it.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

item.title: Federal Government Again Excludes Minnesota From Investigation of Fatal Shooting
item.description: State officials have resorted to unconventional methods as they press forward with their own inquiries into the killings of Alex Jeffrey Pretti and Renee Good.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Minnesota officials said they aimed to have their Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, which typically takes the lead in police shootings, work the investigation, either concurrently or in partnership with the federal government.

item.title: Family of Alex Pretti, the Man Shot in Minnesota, Says They Are Heartbroken and Angry
item.description: In a statement, the parents of the man slain in Minneapolis said that their son “wanted to make a difference.”
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial at the site where Alex Jeffrey Pretti, a nurse and Minneapolis resident, was killed by federal agents.

item.title: Eleanor Holmes Norton Files to End Re-election Campaign
item.description: It was not clear whether Washington’s 88-year-old veteran delegate, who has been in declining health but has insisted she would seek re-election, was aware of the filing.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

media:content.media:credit: André Chung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The campaign of Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton of Washington, D.C., the 88-year-old Democrat, filed paperwork to officially end her campaign for re-election.

item.title: Floyd Vivino, Throwback Comedian Known as Uncle Floyd, Dies at 74
item.description: His silly, vaudeville-style variety show was filled with his piano playing, skits, puppets and guest stars like Cyndi Lauper and Bon Jovi.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:credit: MPIRock/MediaPunch, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Mr. Vivino in 1984. He was sometimes compared to Soupy Sales, a slapstick comic who hosted a syndicated children’s program. Uncle Floyd’s silly absurdism also seemed to augur the arrival of Pee-wee Herman.

item.title: For Trump, the Truth in Minneapolis Is What He Says It Is
item.description: The Trump team has advanced one-sided narratives to justify each of the killings, even when bystander video shows something else entirely.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump has found that putting out a story line early and repeating it often can convince a sizable share of the public that does not credit contrary evidence.

item.title: Another East Coast Storm? Don’t Buy the Hype Just Yet.
item.description: After a computer model began hinting that another storm could be on the way, meteorologists sought to tamp down speculation.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones

media:content.media:credit: Ron Frehm/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Larchmont, N.Y., in 1993. A storm that winter brought widespread heavy snow and paralyzed the East Coast for days.

item.title: The Trump Administration Is Lying to Our Faces. Congress Must Act.
item.description: The Trump administration is once again engaged in a perversion of justice.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times

item.title: CEOs of Target and Minnesota’s Biggest Companies Call for ‘De-Escalation’ After Shooting
item.description: The letter from chief executives at some of the state’s most recognizable companies like Target and Cargill stops short of condemning the recent killings by federal immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch

media:content.media:credit: Adam Gray/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Federal immigration agents outside a Target in St. Paul, Minn., on Sunday.

item.title: Amid Two-Week Internet Blackout, Some Iranians Are Getting Back Online
item.description: Many in Iran are gaining brief and unexplained windows of online connectivity, offering a widening glimpse of the extent of the government crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Sanam Mahoozi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tehran in October, before the internet crackdown.

item.title: Marian Goodman, Eminent New York Art Dealer, Dies at 97
item.description: Although known for promoting German painters, she also sought out artists who shunned painting in favor of newer mediums, like photography and film.
item.dc:creator: Deborah Solomon

media:content.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Marian Goodman in 2016 in her gallery in New York. She played a major role in bringing avant-garde European art to prominence in the 1980s.

item.title: Geese Gives ‘Saturday Night Live’ Viewers Something to Talk About
item.description: The buzzy Brooklyn band brought its off-kilter aesthetic to network TV this weekend, with performances that were both confounding and audacious.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: Museums From Texas to Massachusetts Close for Storm, but Broadway Shows Go On
item.description: The Smithsonian said all of its museums, research centers and the National Zoo would be closed on Sunday and Monday. Most Broadway shows were still expected to make their curtains.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A snowy Sunday in Manhattan.

item.title: Demands for Minneapolis Shooting Investigation Grow as Trump Officials Blame Victim
item.description: A judge ordered federal authorities not to destroy evidence from a fatal shooting by immigration agents. Videos directly contradict descriptions of the encounter by administration officials.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: Storm Pummels Eastern U.S., Shattering Temperature Records
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
